thread.title: Photo: Burning wreckage at the scene of a place crash involving a F-16 and Cessna - @postandcourier
thread.title_full: Photo: Burning wreckage at the scene of a place crash involving a F-16 and Cessna - @postandcourier

author: Shelley Ng
title: Photo: Burning wreckage at the scene of a place crash involving a F-16 and Cessna - @postandcourier
text:
Jul 7 2015 11:31 am Jul 7 12:57 pm Authorities are investigating a multiple plane crash in Moncks Corner. (Facebook) × An F-16 military jet and a Cessna 150C private airplane collided Tuesday morning in the skies over Berkeley County, the Federal Aviation Administration said. 
2005 
18 April 
An Air Force Lockheed Martin F-16DJ Block 50D Fighting Falcon, of the 55th Fighter Squadron, 20th Fighter Wing, based at Shaw Air Force Base crashes in a marsh next to the Ashley River in Charleston. The two crew members, Maj. Steve Granger and Lt. Col. Maurice Salcedo, both assigned to Ninth Air Force Stan Eval and flying with the 77th Fighter Squadron, ejected safely. Both the main power and backup power failed moments before the crash, the pilot said. 
2007 
21 April 
A Navy Blue Angels McDonnell-Douglas F/A-18 Hornet crashes into a residential neighborhood while performing at an airshow in Beaufort, killing the pilot. Military investigators blame pilot for his fatal crash. A report obtained by The Associated Press said Lt. Comndr. Kevin Davis got disoriented and crashed after not properly tensing his abdominal muscles to counter the gravitational forces of a high-speed turn. 
2009 
October 
Pilot error is blamed in the fatal two-plane collision that killed an F-16 flyer during a training exercise off the South Carolina coast. Air Force Capt. Nicholas Giglio died in the crash and was faulted for the accident in which instructor-pilot Capt. Lee Bryant was able to recover safely before landing his damaged jet at Charleston Air Force Base. Both flyers had left from Shaw Air Force Base near Sumter for a nighttime mission. According to the flight’s timetable, at about 10:24 p.m. the planes were returning to Shaw when Giglio performed what was described as an “improper night rejoin” that failed to properly account for the position of the other plane. 
2010 
10 March 
A Marine Corps McDonnell-Douglas F/A-18D Hornet crashed into the Atlantic Ocean, app. 35 miles east of St. Helena Sound after a double engine failure and a fire. Both pilots ejected and were floating in an inflatable life raft for about one hour before they were rescued by a Coast Guard helicopter. 
2 May 
A US Army Boeing AH-64 Apache helicopter carrying two soldiers of the 116th Aviation Group was participating in a routine drill when it crashed on a ramp while taxiing at McEntire Joint National Guard Base shortly before 2 p.m.Both crew were taken to hospital. Pilot 1st Lt. Jonathan Shively, Jr, 33, of Jamestown, died of injuries, but second pilot, Chief Warrant Officer Roger Carpenter, 46, of Spartanburg, was in stable condition. 
*Source: assorted web sites and Post and Courier archives The midair collision was reported around 11 a.m. about 11 miles north of Charleston, FAA spokesman Jim Peters said. Peters said he did not immediately have any further details, including information on the fates of the pilots and whether any passengers were onboard. 
LIVE MAP 
For a live map of the crash, including tweets and other information as it becomes available, go to postandcourier.com/live-map . Witnesses near Lewisfield Plantation reported hearing what sounded like an explosion before the Cessna went down and crashed into a watery rice field while the jet veered eastward. Photos taken by onlookers of the F-16 Fighting Falcon wreckage showed “55” and a pair of dice painted on the metal. The 55th Fighter Squadron is part of the 20th Fighter Wing, which operates at Shaw Air Force Base near Sumter. A spokesman for the base would not immediately confirm that a jet from there had been involved in the collision. The S.C. Air National Guard reported that none of its planes are believed to be involved in the accident. The Cessna was reported to be down near Lewisfield Plantation near Moncks Corner, where there are reports of parts on a roadway. The plantation is on the upper Cooper River and near Lake Moultrie and U.S. Highway 52. Another possible crash site is the nearby Mulberry Plantation. Wayne Ware, who lives on McCrae Drive just south of Lewisfield Plantation, was going for a walk when he heard the collision. “I didn’t see it; I heard it,” Ware said. “I turned around, and I saw the jet. Pieces started falling out of the sky. His engine is lying right there at the campground.” First-responders reported seeing a “debris field” from the F-16 near Medway Plantation, which is south of the other locations. Emergency personnel were told not to touch any of the parts, whether in the woods or the water, according to radio communications. Responders also were told to stay upwind of the F-16 crash site because of the potential for exposure to hydrazine, a toxic fuel used by the aircraft. Michael Mule, spokesman for Berkeley County, said emergency responders had set up an incident command post at the Big Lots shopping plaza at 1013 Old Highway 52. Schuyler Kropf, Bo Petersen and Brenda Rindge contributed to this report. Reach Andrew Knapp at 937-5414 or twitter.com/offlede. Keywords
